awd_titl_txt: QLCI-CG: Towards a Boston Area Quantum Science and Engineering Institute
awd_abstract_narration:
The Quantum Leap Challenge Institutes (QLCI) program is part of the Quantum Leap, one of the research Big Ideas promoted by the National Science Foundation. This award is a QLCI Conceptualization Grant, which supports activities to build capacity among teams planning for the large-scale, interdisciplinary Challenge Institute projects that aim to advance the frontiers of quantum information science and engineering. Research at these Institutes will span the focus areas of quantum computation, quantum communication, quantum simulation, and/or quantum sensing. The Institutes are expected to foster multidisciplinary approaches to specific scientific, technological, and workforce development goals in these fields.
 
This Conceptualization Grant will develop well-formulated plans for a future Challenge Institute proposal along the themes of 1) algorithms, architecture, and platforms for quantum simulation, and 2) quantum sensors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The ambitious initial goal of the QLCI-CG was to bring together the expertise of the tremendously talented and productive quantum community in the State of Massachusetts and establish the Commonwealth as the world leader in the Quantum 2.0 innovation economy. Even though the COVID-19 pandemic intervened and the initial goal was not achieved, the research, training, and outreach efforts developed through the planning process of a Boston Area QLCI resulted in (i) cross-institutional research collaborations in promising novel areas of research; (ii) stronger interdisciplinary interactions across academic units within individual institutions; and (iii) a robust conversation around the development of quantum science and technology career pathways that engaged Boston, Harvard, and Northeastern Universities, Boston College and all campuses of the University of Massachusetts, as well as the Massachusetts Technology Collaborative, the Commonwealth of Massachusetts Executive Office of Education, the City of Boston, the Boston School System, and Museum of Science.

Once the Boston Area Quantum Leap Challenge Institute was abandoned in favor of a Harvard-MIT led submission, the QLCI planning efforts were redirected towards supporting the development of a BU-wide strategy and plan for future investments in areas of unique competitive advantage for the University.

Summarizing some of the outcomes of the QLCI-CG:

(a) There are at least five interdisciplinary research collaborations involving BU, Harvard, and MIT Lincoln labs that were inspired by the planning activities of the QLCI-CG each of which resulted in publications (one published and four submitted).

(b) Using the blueprint established through the efforts of the QLCI-CG BU launched a yearlong ?Quantum Convergence? Focused Research Program (FRP), funded by the Hariri Institute for Computing and Computational Science & Engineering.  The activities of the FRP cemented collaborations across the departments of Physics, Chemistry, Computer Science, Mathematics and Statistics, and Electrical and Computer Engineering. The workshops organized under the umbrella of the FRP also aim to engage other institutions in the Boston area in research, education, and workforce development projects that will serve the broader Quantum Innovation economy of the Commonwealth.

(c) The Physics Departments led the development of an NSF NRT proposal titled "Building the Quantum Science & Technology Workforce",  a collaboration with the Departments of Chemistry, and Computer Science in the College of Arts and Sciences and the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in the College of Engineering. The BU proposal, which was submitted for the 2023-2024 competition focuses on training a young generation of physicists, computer scientists and engineers to contribute to both the fundamental and applied aspects of the quantum technological revolution. Beyond its academic programs the NRT will support Summer Internships for a diverse group of undergraduates who will be mentored by program faculty and graduate students. The NRT also plans public lectures and events highlighting the most exciting features of quantum mechanics and their implications for quantum computing and next-gen devices.

(d) "Quantum Worlds: Science or Science Fiction?": this is a course developed by the PI for BU's Kilachand Honors College, addressed primarily to non-STEM students. The focus of the course is to acquaint students with the wonderous world of quantum mechanics. The main vision of the course is to inspire and facilitate a conceptual understanding of quantum physics not through complex mathematics but through story telling. The goal is to imagine a society that functions according to quantum rules and to use short sci-fi stories to exemplify specific quantum principles and behaviors. In parallel to introducing the science concepts, the course will explore science fiction and its different sub-genres (hard and soft sci-fi, dystopias, cyberpunk, steampunk, etc.), as well as its impact on real-world science. 

(e) The combined QLCI and FRP efforts led to the development of a university-wide hiring plan, the first stage of which was recently approved by the BU administration and involves a cluster hire of six faculty across multiple academic units.

(f)  The QLCI-CG was also instrumental in building connections with industry partners who are critical in the development of BU's Quantum 2.0 focused training, research, and outreach programs. These include Brookhaven National Lab, Draper Laboratories, IBM, MIT Lincoln Laboratories, QuEra, Raytheon, Zapata Computing.

(g)   As a result of the QLCI-CG outreach planning activities BU is currently leading the development of a Boston Area STEM education and outreach project, referred to as "Quantum Imagination", which is meant to rekindle collaborations with the Massachusetts Technology Collaborative, the Commonwealth of Massachusetts Executive Office of Education, the City of Boston, the Boston School System, and Museum of Science, and the Boston Ballet that were initiated through the initial QLCI-CG initiative. One of the main goals of this project is to use "quantum imagination" and ongoing career development mentoring to maximize the chances that students, and especially those from underserved populations, are propelled through the educational pipeline and are prepared to transition into technical careers (possibly as quantum engineers).
